text:
Yeah. I think the best thing is probably just to take your history of wins and losses (at the market level) and run through the calculation for your own case.

In all honesty I would previously have answered your original question with the opinion that the lowest comm rate is always best because of the 50/50 calculation but I'm hesitating from disagreeing with <@U01DCR5PXDY> because I know that he's smart so maybe I'm wrong.

If you do work through your actual case I'd be interested to see the results.

text:
When this gambling stuff dries up there is no way I will go back to software dev. I'm probably quite unemployable now in that regard anyway as a lot of places seeing a CV gap run a mile. I'd probably try private tutoring of something like that. Or maybe something totally different.
I totally agree with you though. By far the biggest perk of this for me is the freedom from commuting, being answerable to an arsehole manager, irritating colleagues etc. I'm not exactly a Victor Meldrew clone, but when I look back to some of the absolute tools with which I have had to share office space, the thought of returning to that dynamic makes me shudder.

text: Great thread. I’m currently following a similar path to you Andy - brute forcing things until I find something consistently profitable. I’m playing in the greyhounds market at the moment. Need to bite the bullet and implement simulation and backtesting as my feedback loop is so slow in my current workflow (essentially AB testing the same strategy with different thresholds running live)

text:
Thinking about my prices only betting (no TPD) I always have variables on two levels:

First - something that tells me that there are likely to be value bets SOMEWHERE in the market - so that's generally something to do with volatility.

Second - something that tells me which runners are likely value to back and which to lay.

More specifically: I estimate the total value available in the market, divvy it up among the runners and re-make the book to 100% (in an embarrassingly shit way) and then take a stab at what price is likely to match on the runners where the discrepancy between my price and a likely matchable price is sufficient.

I'm not saying that that's the only way to do it, or even the best and in all honesty my prices betting is a shadow of what it once was but for what it's worth that's how I do it.

Also - just to reiterate: Do be careful because really that's the easy part. The hard part is the market impact, feedback etc, it's very easy to come un-stuck due to that stuff even if your underlying logic is sound.

elements.text:
Thinking about my prices only betting (no TPD) I always have variables on two levels:

First - something that tells me that there are likely to be value bets SOMEWHERE in the market - so that's generally something to do with volatility.

Second - something that tells me which runners are likely value to back and which to lay.

More specifically: I estimate the total value available in the market, divvy it up among the runners and re-make the book to 100% (in an embarrassingly shit way) and then take a stab at what price is likely to match on the runners where the discrepancy between my price and a likely matchable price is sufficient.

I'm not saying that that's the only way to do it, or even the best and in all honesty my prices betting is a shadow of what it once was but for what it's worth that's how I do it.

Also - just to reiterate: Do be careful because really that's the easy part. The hard part is the market impact, feedback etc, it's very easy to come un-stuck due to that stuff even if your underlying logic is sound.

text:
So some good points learner by me tonight:
1. You can run Flumine sumulation from compressed data, I can now simulate a whole year at once, nice one <@U4H19D1D2> 
2. EV_vs_BSP is great to visualize actual startegy performance
3. You need a decent size dataset to evaluate a strategy, ie.1 year! as you can see below this "fitted" strategy can perform seemingly well for a few months in a row, but in the end of the day although +ve, it is highly likely just random!!
 1 year backtest from compressed .gz data:

text:
I think you might have completely misinterpreted me Misha, my point wasn’t that the world is binary, it was that your behaviour is on one extreme end, for example when you say that any advice you received would make no difference, and then suggested that you don’t know any successful people who do take advice.
It looks like we’re agreed, although rather than “adopt some advice, ignore others”, I’d probably phrase it as consider all advice, but don’t act on all of it. Not sure what your teenagers have to do with it though.

elements.text:
I think you might have completely misinterpreted me Misha, my point wasn’t that the world is binary, it was that your behaviour is on one extreme end, for example when you say that any advice you received would make no difference, and then suggested that you don’t know any successful people who do take advice.
It looks like we’re agreed, although rather than “adopt some advice, ignore others”, I’d probably phrase it as consider all advice, but don’t act on all of it. Not sure what your teenagers have to do with it though.

text: I was only being specific about this advice. Yes, "consider all advice, but don’t act on all of it" is a better phrase. Often the person who is hearing the advice has a lot more info about particular circumstances that the person giving advice doesn't (as it true here). The second point is it is often better to get the experience if it doesn't have permanent negative outcomes. In my case, we were always well above $0, so losing money that I won in the first place and haven't "banked" is no big deal for me. That money was no required to pay my mortgage, etc. The point about teenagers is actually correct. Mine DO have to learn by ignoring the advice and failing for themselves. It's actually how we all mostly learn. You have to do for yourself first

elements.text: I was only being specific about this advice. Yes, "consider all advice, but don’t act on all of it" is a better phrase. The second point is it is often better to get the experience if it doesn't have permanent negative outcomes. That money was no required to pay my mortgage, etc. The point about teenagers is actually correct. Mine DO have to learn by ignoring the advice and failing for themselves. It's actually how we all mostly learn. You have to do for yourself first
